title: 108_hr5226
content: SECTION 1. CROP DISASTER ASSISTANCE. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "additional coverage," "insurable commodity," and "noninsurable commodity" related to agricultural commodities and insurance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act. Producers on a farm can receive emergency financial assistance for crop losses in 2003 or 2004 due to damaging weather conditions, as authorized by the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996. The Secretary will provide assistance for crop losses due to damaging weather conditions, following the same procedures as outlined in a previous Act. Producers on a farm may not be eligible for assistance for losses to an insurable commodity. Producers on a farm may not receive assistance for crop losses if they did not obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities by the deadline. The Secretary may waive assistance eligibility requirements for producers on a farm if they enter into a contract agreeing to obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities by the deadline. The Secretary may waive assistance eligibility requirements for producers on a farm if they enter into a contract agreeing to obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities by the applicable State filing deadline. In case of a violation, the producer must reimburse the Secretary for the full assistance amount received. Payment limitations apply to assistance provided for crop losses. The Secretary may include crop insurance payments or payments under specific acts when applying the limitation on assistance for crop losses. The total assistance for crop losses cannot exceed 95 percent of the crop's estimated value in the absence of losses. The producer's assistance for crop losses may be reduced by the amount received from Florida Disaster Programs. SEC. 2. LIVESTOCK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide emergency financial assistance for livestock losses in counties designated as emergencies after January 1, 2003. Producers can choose to receive payments for 2003 or 2004 losses, but not both. Some funds will be allocated for the American Indian livestock program. The Secretary will provide emergency financial assistance for livestock losses in designated counties after January 1, 2003. Producers can receive payments for either 2003 or 2004 losses. The Secretary will not penalize producers who take actions to reduce livestock numbers during disaster conditions for eligibility under the livestock assistance program. The producer's livestock count for grazing during the production year is needed for assistance. The Tree Assistance Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide emergency assistance to producers who suffered tree losses between December 1, 2003, and December 31, 2004. An additional $15,000,000 will be used to provide reimbursement to eligible orchardists under the tree assistance program. Credit Corporation will reimburse eligible forest landowners for tree losses during a specified period for commercial timber production under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. The Secretary of Agriculture will allocate an additional $50,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for the Emergency Conservation Program. Participants will receive the maximum cost share percentage allowed. The Commodity Credit Corporation will be utilized to implement this Act. Regulations will be established for the program. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedural requirements. The Secretary of Agriculture can implement regulations for the Act without following certain procedural requirements, known as the "Paperwork Reduction Act". Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted using authority provided under section 808 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. OFFSET. Amends Section 1241(a)(3) of the Food Security Act of 1985 to allocate $6,037,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2014.
